results.title: Planet Earth
results.creator_credit: Coastal Community Colleges and David P. Stone
results.brief_description:
Episode number 20 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
From the tempest and chaos of the early beginnings of our solar system, the planets were born. It is believed that from a collision of smaller bodies orbiting the sun, bigger objects were formed into the planets. The Earth underwent a severe heating and cooling which accounts for its structure. This episode examines the Earth from a planetary perspective. Unique in our solar system, the planet contains large bodies of water and an oxygen, rather than carbon dioxide based atmosphere; optimum conditions for the formation of organic life. In terms of the Earth’s geological age, the presence of life happened relatively late in the Earths’ life cycle.

results.title: Planes, trains and automobiles
results.brief_description: It’s Thanksgiving and Neal Page (Steve Martin) is looking forward to spending some quality time with the family. While on the flight home, Neal is seated next to obnoxious shower curtain ring salesman Del Griffith (John Candy). When a snow storm causes their plane to be rerouted, the two are reluctantly united by their misfortune. Thus begins a disastrous chain of events that transcends all forms of public transport and threatens to make Neal miss Thanksgiving all together.

results.title: Plane mates
results.creator_credit: Kenneth S. Cox and Donald Crombie
results.brief_description: A dramatised story for children showing the wide interest in and use of aircraft in Australia. Shows aerial ambulance, radio-controlled model planes, a trip in a light plane over Sydney and finally the Qantas jets. Includes a brief history of aviation and information on what makes planes stay up.

results.title: Plan your maintenance
results.brief_description: The problem of maintenance in factories. An over-strained maintenance engineer collapses on the job, and the manager and his deputy set about selecting an assistant, to take over when the first man retires. Three candidates discuss the value of lubrication routine, spare parts in store, scheduling of maintenance, job cards and records, cost analysis, staff conferences and other factors. Underlying policy questions and personal attitudes come up in the course of the interviews and flashbacks to situations on the job.

results.title: Plan for living
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and Eric Thompson
results.brief_description: Shows scenes where early settlers landed in Australia; early views of the cities of Australia; construction of buildings post 1949 and general living conditions and development of the cities of Australia.

results.title: Plan for coal
results.creator_credit: Data Film Productions and Stuart Legg
results.brief_description: Shows the British coal industry; its history and significance from the first World War, through the depression of the 1930s to the present day. Some indication is given of long-term planning being carried out by the National Coal Board for the stabilisation and modernisation of the industry. Shows some of the new equipment being used. Narrated by Howard Crawford, Michael Goodliffe.

results.title: Plan 9 from outer space = Grave robbers from outer space
results.creator_credit: Reynolds Pictures and Edward Wood Jr
results.brief_description: The local authorities join forces with the military to ward off an invasion of flying saucers. Undeterred, the aliens continue their attempt to conquer Earth by resurrecting corpses from a San Fernando cemetery. “Plan 9 from outer space” has been described as the worst film ever made. This dubious honour has led to the cult status and notoriety the film enjoys to this day, proving that any publicity is good publicity. Those who have seen Tim Burton’s homage, “Ed Wood”, will enjoy seeing this original masterpiece. Bela Lugosi played the definitive vampire as Count Dracula in Tod Browning’s 1931 classic horror. In “Plan 9”, he revives his ghoulish persona in this, his final screen role.

results.title: Plains people
results.brief_description: Contrasts the life styles of the Masai of Kenya and the cowboys of Montana. Shows the Masai’s dependence on the land, use of cattle and division of labour. A brief segment on the cowboys shows a cattle roundup. No other credits available.
